author: Kim Janssen
title: Chicago employees of Barneys New York reject union
text:
Chicago employees of upscale department store Barneys New York have narrowly voted against unionizing, following an angry dispute over a company policy requiring sales associates to push store credit cards or face disciplinary action.
But union organizers unhappy at their 40-35 loss in Saturday's election say they will appeal the vote to the National Labor Relations Board, citing what they call "irregularities" in how the election was carried out.
More than 50 of the Gold Coast store's sales associates and shipping and distribution workers signed cards indicating they wished to unionize ahead of Saturday's vote, according to Workers United communications director Carlos Ginard.
But some of that support for the union evaporated after management called workers into one-on-one meetings and used "scare tactics" to twist their arms, Ginard said.
"We are really disappointed â€” we had a very good relationship with Barneys in New York for more than 50 years," he added.
Workers at the Oak Street store were complaining about pay fairness, and a recent policy change that required all sales associates to open two new store credit cards for customers per month, or face disciplinary action.
That policy was rescinded in the wake of the organizing effort, though Barneys continued to warn that workers caught failing to ask customers to apply for a card could be disciplined.

The store credit card is owned by Comenity Bank, whose parent company, Alliance Data Systems, bought Barneys' private-label credit card portfolio for $37.1 million in 2013, according to government filings.
Ginard said that staff fear that Barneys has a plan to force out older, more experienced staff and replace them with younger, less experienced workers.
Barneys management did not immediately return calls seeking comment Monday morning.
Ginard said unionization votes in Beverly Hills and Las Vegas are pending. Barneys workers in New York and New Jersey have been unionized for decades, having signed a deal with the store's late founder, Barney Pressman, he said.
